revision.text:
The '''Andean passport''' is a [[passport]] for [[South America]]n [[country|countries]] that are members of the [[Andean Community of Nations]] (ACN).
==Origin and use==
The Andean passport was created in June 2001 pursuant to ACN Decisión 504. This passport is based on a standard model containing harmonised features of nomenclature and security based on the recommendations of the [[International Civil Aviation Organization]] (ICAO). The member states of the ACN agreed to phase in new Andean passports bearing the official name of the regional body in [[Spanish language|Spanish]] by January 2005, although previously issued national passports will be valid until their expiry date.
The passport is effective in [[Bolivia]], [[Colombia]], [[Ecuador]], [[Peru]] and formerly, in [[Venezuela]]. Because [[Venezuela]] left the ACN in 2006, the country no longer issues Andean passports, and it is most likely to start issuing a new [[MERCOSUR]]-style passport as the country became a full member of that organization. Venezuelan ACN passports issued are valid until its expiration date. The last Venezuelan ACN passports were more likely to expire between 2011 and 2012.
==Basic features== The Andean passport features: * a passbook type format with rounded edges measuring {{convert|88|mm|in}} by {{convert|125|mm|in}}. * a cover and back cover in “bordeaux” [[color]]. * legends printed in [[Gold (color)|gold]] color. * Above the national seal of the issuing country, the cover has the legend "'''COMUNIDAD ANDINA'''", which is centered and printed in larger [[font]]s. Below the seal is printed the official name of the member country. * the bottom of the cover has the word "'''PASAPORTE'''" ([[Spanish language|Spanish]]), with "PASSPORT" ([[English language|English]]) immediately below in smaller type.
==Gallery of Andean passports== <gallery widths="120px" heights="120px" perrow="4"> BolPassportFace02.png|<center>{{flagicon|Bolivia}} [[Bolivian passport]]</center> ColombianPassport.jpg|<center>{{flagicon|Colombia}} [[Colombian passport]]</center> Pasaporte_de_la_República_del_Ecuador.jpg|<center>{{flagicon|Ecuador}} [[Ecuadorian passport]]</center> Peru passport.jpg|<center>{{flagicon|Peru}} [[Peruvian passport]]</center> </gallery>
==External links== *[https://web.archive.org/web/20060526171502/http://www.comunidadandina.org/ingles/normativa/D525e.htm DECISION 525: Minimum specific technical characteristics of Andean Passport nomenclature and security]
{{Pan-Americanism}} {{Passports}}

The '''Arusha Peace and Reconciliation Agreement''', widely known as the '''Arusha Accords''' ({{lang-fr|Accords d'Arusha}}), was a transitional [[peace treaty]] which brought the [[Burundian Civil War]] to an end{{fact|date=September 2018}}. The agreement, negotiated in [[Arusha]], [[Tanzania]] under the mediation of former Tanzanian president [[Julius Nyerere]], were signed on 28 August 2000.<ref name=Nantulya>{{cite web|last1=Nantulya|first1=Paul|title=Burundi: Why the Arusha Accords are Central|url=https://africacenter.org/spotlight/burundi-why-the-arusha-accords-are-central/|website=Africa Center for Strategic Studies|accessdate=12 May 2018|date=5 August 2015}}</ref>
The Accords were based on four points of agreement:<ref name=Nantulya/> #A power-sharing formula, based on an agreed formula of [[Racial quota|ethnic quota]]s in politics #Representation of all parties in the state bureaucracy #Constitutional restrictions to prevent any single party becoming excessively powerful #Pathways to integrate former rebels and minority groups in the [[Military of Burundi|Burundian armed forces]].
The central tenets of the Arusha Accords were subsequently added to the [[Constitution of Burundi]].<ref name=Nantulya/>
==References== {{Reflist}}
==External links==
*[https://www.brookings.edu/wp-content/uploads/2016/07/Burundi_Arusha-Peace-and-Reconciliation-Agreement-for-Burundi.pdf Arusha Peace and Reconciliation Agreement for Burundi] (original text) at the [[Brookings Institution]]

revision.text:
{{Infobox song contest entry | song = {{flagicon|Portugal}} "Baunilha e chocolate" | image = | caption = | year = 1995 | country = Portugal | artist = Tó Cruz | as = | with = | language = Portuguese | languages = | composer = António Vitorino d'Almeida | lyricist = António Vitorino d'Almeida,
[[Rosa Lobato de Faria]] | conductor = Thilo Krassmann | place = 21st | points = 5 | lyrics = [http://www.diggiloo.net/?1995pt from Diggiloo Thrush] | prev = Chamar a música | prev_link = Chamar a música | next = O meu coração não tem cor | next_link = O meu coração não tem cor }} '''"Baunilha e chocolate"''' ("Vanilla and chocolate") was the [[Portugal|Portuguese]] entry in the [[Eurovision Song Contest 1995]], performed in [[Portuguese language|Portuguese]] by [[Tó Cruz]]. The song is inspired by [[urban contemporary|urban music]] and features Cruz singing to his "sweetheart with white skin" while musing on their interracial relationship (Cruz is black). He suggests that this could only have been made possible via the intrepid maritime history of their country, and sings about the spices and cultural knowledge that were brought back to Portugal as a result of this history. The song was performed sixteenth on the night, following the [[United Kingdom]]'s [[Love City Groove]] with "[[Love City Groove (song)|Love City Groove]]" and preceding [[Cyprus]]' [[Alexandros Panayi]] with "[[Sti Fotia]]". At the close of voting, it had received 5 points, placing 21st in a field of 23. It was succeeded as [[Portugal in the Eurovision Song Contest|Portuguese representative]] at the [[Eurovision Song Contest 1996|1996 contest]] by [[Lúcia Moniz]] with "[[O meu coração não tem cor]]". {{Eurovision Song Contest 1995}} {{Portugal in the Eurovision Song Contest}} [[Category:Eurovision songs of Portugal]] [[Category:Portuguese-language songs]] [[Category:Eurovision songs of 1995]] [[Category:1995 songs]] [[Category:Songs with lyrics by Rosa Lobato de Faria]] {{portugal-stub}}

The airport is the largest in the country, and as such, is the primary entry point into the country by air with flights to Africa and Europe. The Cotonou [[VOR-DME]] (Ident: '''TYE''') is on the field. The Cotonou [[non-directional beacon]] (Ident: '''CO''') is located {{convert|1.4|nmi|km|order=flip|abbr=off}} northeast of the airport. ==Airlines and destinations== ===Passenger=== accidents== * [[UTAGE Flight 141]]: On 25 December 2003, the airplane crashed in the [[Bight of Benin]], killing 151 of the 163 occupants, most of them Lebanese. ==Replacement== In 1974, it was decided to move the operations of the Cotonou international airport to a new facility in [[Glo-Djigbé]]. Lack of funding quickly stopped the project. Plans were revived in 2011 and President [[Yayi Boni]] presided at a ceremonial start to the construction of the new airport, using South African funding.{{cite web|title=Bénin : Glo-Djigbé, un aéroport flambant neuf à 360 milliards|url=http://www.ambassade-benin.fr/benin-glo-djigbe-un-aeroport-flambant-neuf-a-360-milliards/|archive-url=https://archive.is/20130706154956/http://www.ambassade-benin.fr/benin-glo-djigbe-un-aeroport-flambant-neuf-a-360-milliards/|dead-url=yes|archive-date=6 July 2013|accessdate=6 July 2013|author=Beninese Embassy in Paris, France}} Construction on the new facility appears to have stalled again.{{cite web|last=Teiga|first=Marcus Boni|title=Bénin – Que sont les grands projets économiques devenus?|url=http://blog.slateafrique.com/echos-du-benin/2012/06/27/benin-%E2%80%93-que-sont-les-grands-projets-economiques-devenus/|publisher=SlateAfrique|accessdate=6 July 2013|language=French|date=27 June 2012|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140308233448/http://blog.slateafrique.com/echos-du-benin/2012/06/27/benin-%E2%80%93-que-sont-les-grands-projets-economiques-devenus/|archivedate=8 March 2014|df=dmy-all}} Meanwhile, improvements to the Cotonou airport were initiated.[http://www.aeroport-cotonou.com/informations_aeroport.php?idnew=285 The President visits the airport] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160806190626/http://www.aeroport-cotonou.com/informations_aeroport.php?idnew=285 |date=6 August 2016 }} French[http://www.aeroport-cotonou.com/informations_aeroport.php?idnew=26 The President inaugurates improvements] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160806193212/http://www.aeroport-cotonou.com/informations_aeroport.php?idnew=26 |date=6 August 2016 }} French ==References== {{reflist}} == External links == * [http://www.aeroport-cotonou.com/ Cotonou airport] – Cotonou airport website * [https://www.openstreetmap.org/#map=13/6.3452/2.3950 OpenStreetMap - {{Orphan|date=March 2012}}
The '''Clerk of the Weather''' or the '''Weather Clerk''' is "an imaginary functionary facetiously supposed to direct the weather."<ref>Thomas Davidson, ''Chambers's twentieth century dictionary of the English language'', 1907, ''s.v.'' 'clerk'</ref>
The Clerk of the Weather appears in children's stories by [[Rose Fyleman]] ("The Weather Clerk"),<ref>Rose Fyleman, ''Eight Little Plays for Children'', London, 1924</ref> [[Robert Swindells]] (''The Weather-Clerk''),<ref>Robert Swindells (author), Petula Stone (illustrator), ''The weather-clerk'', London, 1979</ref> and others.
He also appears in facetious turns of phrase such as "another fine day was supplied by the clerk of the weather".<ref>"A Harbor of Rest", ''Warsaw (Indiana) Daily Times'', 8 October 1887, p. 1 [https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=eoZHAAAAIBAJ&sjid=tHwMAAAAIBAJ&pg=6110,2804305 Google News]</ref>
In [[Nathaniel Hawthorne]]'s short story "A Visit to the Clerk of the Weather" (1836), he is imagined as a 6000-year-old man living on another planet. Within his dwelling, he has a stock of [[thunderbolts]], [[rainbow]]s, [[hailstones]], sacks of [[wind]], and a "portable tempest, firmly secured with iron bands". His companions include [[Jack Frost]] and [[Spring (season)|Spring]].<ref>Nathaniel Hawthorne, "A Visit to the Clerk of the Weather", ''[[American Monthly Magazine (1833)|American Monthly Magazine]]'' '''1'''(NS):[https://books.google.com/books?id=aVlFAAAAYAAJ&pg=PA483 483]</ref>
In [[Herman Melville]]'s poem "Pebbles" one finds "Though the Clerk of the Weather insist, / And lay down the weather-law, / Pintado and gannet they wist / That the winds blow whither they list / In tempest or flaw"
In [[Samuel Clemens]]' speech at the [[New England Society of New York]] in 1876, he attributed New England weather to "raw apprentices in the Weather Clerk's factory, who experiment and learn how in New England, for board and clothes, and then are promoted to make weather for countries that require a good article, and will take their custom elsewhere if they don't get it."<ref>''The New York Times'', 23 December 1876, quoted in [http://www.twainquotes.com/18761223.html Twain Quotes]</ref>
[[U. A. Fanthorpe]], in her poem "Special", refers to a class of children looking after a dog as 'Clerks of the Weather'.<ref>"Neck Verse", Peterloo Poets, 1992</ref>
==Notes== <references/>
{{Portal |Children's literature}}

revision.text:
{{More references|date=February 2011}} '''Coupe de France de robotique''' is a [[robotics]] competition held in [[La Roche-sur-Yon]] , [[France]], organized by [[Planète Sciences]].
== History == The Coupe de France de robotique (former "E = M6 Cup of robotics", from the Science TV show) is a competition coorganized since 2016 by the association Planète Sciences and the mixed economy company Oryon.
The French Robotics Cup was created in 1994, originally, in partnership with the company VM Productions, (producer until 2005 of the show E = M6), and the association [http://www.planete-sciences.org/national/ Planète Sciences]. The idea comes from Nicolas Goldzahl (then president of VM Productions) who was inspired by a creative class of Professor Woodie Flowers<ref>{{Cite journal|date=2018-03-25|title=Woodie Flowers|url=https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Woodie_Flowers&oldid=832428062|journal=Wikipedia|language=en}}</ref> of the [[Massachusetts Institute of Technology]] (MIT). This course - called the "2.007"<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://ocw.mit.edu/courses/mechanical-engineering/2-007-design-and-manufacturing-i-spring-2009/|title=Design and Manufacturing I|last=Daniel|first=Frey,|website=MIT OpenCourseWare|language=en|access-date=2018-04-25}}</ref> - was given to about 50 students and consisted of participating in a competition in which remote-controlled robots had to be built, two by two, with a different rule each year<ref>{{Citation|last=MIT Mechanical Engineering|title=The Birth of a Hands-On Education|date=2015-12-02|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=dDbPwLODAx0|accessdate=2018-04-25}}</ref>. The goal is to develop students creativity. Nicolas Goldzahl, decided to adapt this idea in France, in two distinct categories: one with remote-controlled robots for college and high school students (Robotics Trophies), the other with autonomous robots for universities and engineering schools ( Robotics cup). To move from the idea to the realization, it was his meeting with the association Planet Science that was decisive. Planet Science wanted at that time to develop its robotics activity, Nicolas Goldzahl proposed to broadcast the event in the show E = M6 he was co-producing with Mac Lesggy. The first year, there were only fifteen participating teams (first location of the competition: Ecole Centrale Paris, now Central Supélec) but the media and the network of Planet Sciences contributed to its rapid development and very quickly this number exceeded the hundred teams from all over France.
The French Robotics Cup takes place every year and, until 2014, was part of the ARTEC festival in [[La Ferté-Bernard]]. In 2015, following the suspension of the organization of the ARTEC festival by the town of La Ferté-Bernard, the French Robotics Cup was looking for a new funding. In 2016 the competition found a new home in Vendée: [[La Roche-sur-Yon]].
==References== <references />
==External links== * [http://www.planete-sciences.org/robot/index.php?section=pages&pageid=79 Planète Sciences page about the competition]

The channel has been dedicated to agriculture and related sectors, which disseminates real-time inputs to farmers on new farming techniques, water conservation and organic farming among other information.{{cite web|url=http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/india/DD-Kisan-set-for-launch-on-May-26/articleshow/47323145.cms|title=DD Kisan set for launch on May 26|newspaper=[[The Times of India]]|date=18 May 2015|accessdate=10 June 2015}}{{cite web|url=http://www.dnaindia.com/india/report-government-considers-launching-dd-kisan-on-modi-government-s-1st-anniversary-2087350|title=Government considers launching 'DD Kisan' on Modi government's 1st anniversary|newspaper=[[Daily News and Analysis]]|date=20 May 2015|accessdate=10 June 2015}} ==History== Ahead of [[Indian general election, 2014]], the [[Bharatiya Janata Party|BJP]] had declared that if they come in power they would try setting up a dedicated channel for Indian Farmers thus giving them an opportunity to watch program related to agriculture and farming 24X7. The public broadcaster Prasar Bharti which currently runs the ''[[Krishi Darshan]]'' program on Doordarshan is one of the longest running programmes on DD National. It was launched on 26 January 1967. ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== *[http://www.ddkisan.in/ Official website] *[https://www.facebook.com/DDkisan.agriculture DD INDIA Programme Schedule] {{CATV}} {{Terrestrial television channels of India}} {{DEFAULTSORT:DD Kisan}} [[Category:Doordarshan]] [[Category:Television channels and stations established in 2015]] [[Category:Direct broadcast satellite services]] [[Category:Indian direct broadcast satellite services]] [[Category:Agriculture in India]] [[Category:Television stations in New Delhi]] [[Category:2015 establishments in India]] [[Category:Modi administration initiatives]] {{India-tv-station-stub}}

revision.text:
The '''Committee on Fisheries''' (PECH) is a [[committee]] of the [[European Parliament]].
[[Alain Cadec]] is the [[Chairman]] (2014-2019).
==Committee mandate== PECH is the European Parliament committee responsible for:
1. the operation and development of the common fisheries policy and its management;
2. the conservation of fishery resources, the management of fisheries and fleets exploiting such resources and marine and applied fisheries research;
3. the common organisation of the market in fishery and aquaculture products and the processing and marketing thereof;
4. structural policy in the fisheries and aquaculture sectors, including the financial instruments and funds for fisheries guidance to support these sectors;
5. the integrated maritime policy as regards fishing activities;
6. sustainable fisheries partnership agreements, regional fisheries organisations and the implementation of international obligations in the field of fisheries.
== Research service == The Committee is directly supported by a research service, the Policy Department for Structural & Cohesion Policies. Most of its research studies and briefings are published online. The papers do not necessarily reflect the view of the Committee.
Recent publications (as of October 2018):
[https://research4committees.blog/2018/09/28/fisheries-in-ireland/ Fisheries in Ireland]
[https://research4committees.blog/2018/09/17/aland-islands/ Åland Islands]
[https://research4committees.blog/2018/07/03/training-of-fishers-2/ Training of Fishers]

[https://research4committees.blog/2018/06/18/fisheries-in-mauritania-and-the-european-union/ Fisheries in Mauritania and the European Union]
[https://research4committees.blog/2018/05/24/landing-obligation-and-choke-species-in-multispecies-and-mixed-fisheries-the-north-western-waters/ Landing Obligation and Choke Species in Multispecies and Mixed Fisheries – The North Western Waters]
[https://research4committees.blog/2018/05/23/landing-obligation-and-choke-species-in-multispecies-and-mixed-fisheries-the-south-western-waters/ Landing Obligation and Choke Species in Multispecies and Mixed Fisheries – The South Western Waters]
[https://research4committees.blog/2018/05/22/landing-obligation-and-choke-species-in-multispecies-and-mixed-fisheries-the-north-sea/ Landing Obligation and Choke Species in Multispecies and Mixed Fisheries – The North Sea]
[https://research4committees.blog/2017/10/20/marine-recreational-and-semi-subsistence-fishing-its-value-and-its-impact-on-fish-stock/ Marine recreational and semi-subsistence fishing – its value and its impact on fish stock]
[https://research4committees.blog/2017/10/27/common-fisheries-policy-and-brexit/ Common Fisheries Policy and BREXIT]
[https://research4committees.blog/2017/10/27/regional-ocean-governance-in-europe-the-role-of-fisheries/ Regional ocean governance in Europe: the role of fisheries]
[https://research4committees.blog/2017/12/06/fisheries-in-japan/ Fisheries in Japan]
[https://research4committees.blog/2018/03/01/small-scale-fisheries-markets-value-chain-promotion-and-labelling/ Small-Scale Fisheries Markets: Value Chain, Promotion and Labelling]
[https://research4committees.blog/2017/10/24/small-scale-fisheries-and-blue-growth-in-the-eu/ Small scale fisheries and “Blue Growth” in the EU]
[https://research4committees.blog/2018/02/27/impact-of-fisheries-partnership-agreements-on-employment-in-the-eu-and-in-third-countries/ Impact of Fisheries Partnership Agreements on Employment in the EU and in Third Countries]
[https://research4committees.blog/2017/11/22/seafood-industry-integration-in-the-eu/ Seafood Industry Integration in the EU]
[https://research4committees.blog/2017/10/24/the-management-of-fishing-fleets-in-outermost-regions/ The Management of Fishing Fleets in Outermost Regions]

{{Use British English|date=August 2011}} {{Use dmy dates|date=August 2011}}
'''James Edward Butler Futtit Farrington''' (originally called Butler; later known universally as Fram)<ref>Stemming from a schoolboy holiday to Framlington-on-Sea [https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/obituaries/1410607/Fram-Farrington.html Daily Telegraph Obituary]</ref> was a key member of a secret [[World War II|wartime]] [[Antarctic]] expeditionary force and the last surviving holder of the Polar Medal in Bronze, abolished after 1941.<ref>{{cite journal|url=https://www.cambridge.org/core/journals/polar-record/article/obituary/B9827BE875A1D87A85D59D6B0ACC588E|title=Obituary: James Edward Butler Futtit Farrington|first=Geoffrey|last=Hattersley-Smith|publisher=|journal=Polar Record|volume=39|issue=3|pages=270–271|accessdate=28 April 2018|via=Cambridge Core|doi=10.1017/S0032247403233192}}</ref>
==Early life== Farrington was born in 1908, in Northern [[Ireland]]. He qualified as a marine radio operator in 1929 and joined the [[British Merchant Navy|Merchant Navy]] where he served for the next 6 years.<ref>{{cite book |last=Haddelsey |first=Stephen |title=Operation Tabarin : Britain's secret wartime expedition to Antarctica, 1944-46 |location=Stroud, UK |publisher=The History Press |year=2014 |isbn=978-0-75249-356-5|pages=63}}</ref>
==First visits to Polar regions== After serving on [[Peninsular and Oriental Steam Navigation Company|P & O]] liners and cargo ships he began his Antarctic career as part of the Discovery Committee,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.soton.ac.uk/library/about/nol/noldiscoverybackgnd.html|title=University Library - University of Southampton|website=www.soton.ac.uk|accessdate=28 April 2018}}</ref> voyaging south to the coasts of [[Enderby Land]], [[Kemp Land]] and [[Mac. Robertson Land]]. Between 1937 and 1938, he served with future Operation Tabarin leader [[James Marr (biologist)|James Marr]] aboard [[RRS William Scoresby|HMS ''William Scoresby'']].<ref>{{cite book |last=Haddelsey |first=Stephen |title=Operation Tabarin : Britain's secret wartime expedition to Antarctica, 1944-46 |location=Stroud, UK |publisher=The History Press |year=2014 |isbn=978-0-75249-356-5|pages=63}}</ref> In addition to his radio duties Farrington took charge of producing the ship's journal ''Pelagic News''. As a ship-based member Farringdon received the Bronze Polar Medal, a distinction which always rankled with him.<ref>It has, however, since been awarded to him after his death: Telegraph Obituary (ibid)</ref>
==Wartime Service== After the outbreak of war, Farrington became an [[Air Ministry]] inspector based at [[Metropolitan-Vickers]] in Manchester, until he was summoned to London for secondment to [[Operation Tabarin]],<ref>a predecessor of the [[British Antarctic Survey]], launched to safeguard British interests south of the [[Falkland Islands]], where both the Argentine and Chilean governments asserted claims to sovereignty [http://www.falklands.gov.fk/pb/fi/World War II-60.htm Further explanation]</ref> under the overall command of Lt-Cdr [[James William Slessor Marr|James Marr]]. Based on [[Deception Island]], in the [[South Shetlands]], Farrington had expected to spend the winter of 1945–46 at [[Hope Bay]], but his sense of duty made him exchange places with a less experienced radio operator.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.antarctic-circle.org/obitsPR.htm|title=ObituariesPR|website=www.antarctic-circle.org|accessdate=28 April 2018}}</ref> Thus, technically, he never wintered on the Antarctic mainland, with the result that he was not awarded the Silver [[Polar Medal]]<ref>[http://www.antarctic.ac.uk/about_bas/publications/bas_history.rtf. Explanation of ruling]</ref>
==Post war== On his return from the Antarctic in 1946, Farrington became a scientific officer with the [[Telecommunications Research Establishment]] at [[Malvern, Worcestershire|Malvern]], moving two years later to the new electronics division at the [[Atomic Energy Research Establishment]], [[Harwell, Oxfordshire|Harwell]]. He retired in 1975 and returned to Northern Ireland in 1989, where he died on 4 October 2002, survived by his wife and son.<ref>{{cite book |last=Haddelsey |first=Stephen |title=Operation Tabarin : Britain's secret wartime expedition to Antarctica, 1944-46 |location=Stroud, UK |publisher=The History Press |year=2014 |isbn=978-0-75249-356-5|pages=229}}</ref>
==Bibliography== Crustacea Amphipoda from Graham Land and the Scotia Arc, Collected By ''Operation Tabarin'' and the Falkland Islands Dependencies Survey 1944–59 Thurston, M. H. Cambridge British Antarctic Survey 1974 ({{ISBN|0856650242}})
==References== {{reflist}}

{{politics of Vatican City}} The post of '''Governor of Vatican City''' ('''''Governatore dello Stato della Città del Vaticano''''' in [[Italian language|Italian]]) was held by Marchese [[Camillo Serafini]] from the foundation of the state in 1929 until his death in 1952. No successor was appointed, and the post itself was not mentioned in the [[Fundamental Law of Vatican City State]] issued by [[Pope John Paul II]] on 26 November 2000, which entered into force on 22 February 2001.
Even during the lifetime of Marchese Serafini, the powers of the Governor were limited by [[Pope Pius XII]] in 1939 by the establishment of the [[Pontifical Commission for Vatican City State]]—consisting of a number of cardinals, originally three, but later increased to seven. The [[President of the Pontifical Commission for Vatican City State|President of this Commission]] has exercised since 1952 the functions that were previously attributed to the Governor. Since 2001, he is also given the title of President of the [[Governorate of the State of Vatican City]].
==External links== * [http://www.unipg.it/francesco.clementi Francesco Clementi: La nuova "Costituzione" dello Stato della Città del Vaticano] * [https://web.archive.org/web/20020105141034/http://www.filodiritto.com/diritto/pubblico/internazionale/cittadelvaticano.htm Luca Martini: Le caratteristiche peculiari dello Stato della Città del Vaticano: istituzioni e nuova costituzione] * [https://www.mulino.it/isbn/9788815131515 Sullo Stato della Città del Vaticano], v. F. Clementi, Città del Vaticano, Bologna, Il Mulino, 2009
[[Category:Government of Vatican City]]
{{VaticanCity-stub}}

[[File:Deux exemplaires de la collection de livres Hall of Femmes.jpg|alt=Two books from the Hall of Femmes collection|thumb|440x440px|'''Two books from the Hall of Femmes''' '''collection''']] '''Hall of Femmes''' is a project, based in [[Sweden]], aiming to highlight the work of women in [[art direction]] and [[design]]. The designers Samira Bouabana and Angela Tillman Sperandio founded the project in 2009 and the intention was to revise the design history by talking about and paying tribute to the women who were involved in it. The business includes the Hall of Femmes book series where eight female pioneers in [[graphic design]] are portrayed. The project also includes [[seminars]], [[Film screening|screenings]], talks, [[exhibition]]s and [[podcast]]s.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://halloffemmes.com/about/|title=Hall of Femmes - About |publisher=Hall of Femmes |date=2010-10-16 |accessdate=2014-03-26}}</ref> Hall of Femmes also wants to inspire to a more equal industry and contribute to the future of the design scene. The business is widely established both in Sweden and internationally, and has been written up in magazines like [[the New York Times Magazine]] <ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.nytimes.com/slideshow/2010/06/25/fashion/20100627-pulse-slideshow-4.html?_r=0|title=New York Times Magazine on Hall of Femmes |publisher=New York Times Magazine|date=2010-06-25 |accessdate=2014-03-26}}</ref> as well as [[Creative Review]] <ref>{{cite web|url=http://media.halloffemmes.com/2013/04/CR.pdf|title=Creative Review on Hall of Femmes |publisher=Hall of Femmes |date=2013-04-01 |accessdate=2014-03-26}}</ref> and [[Vanity Fair (magazine)|Vanity Fair]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.vanityfair.com/culture/features/2010/06/art-director-ruth-ansel-slide-show-201006#/slide=16|title=Vanity Fair on Hall of Femmes|publisher=Vanity Fair|date=2010-06-18 |accessdate=2014-03-26}}</ref>
In May 2013 Hall of Femmes organized Design Talks,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.modernamuseet.se/en/Stockholm/Programme/Past-programme/2013/Hall-of-Femmes-Design-Talks/|title=Museum of Modern Art on Design Talks|publisher=The Museum of Modern Art, Stockholm|date=2013-05-01|accessdate=2014-03-26|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140413141731/http://www.modernamuseet.se/en/Stockholm/Programme/Past-programme/2013/Hall-of-Femmes-Design-Talks/|archivedate=2014-04-13|df=}}</ref> a two-day conference at the Museum of Modern Art in Stockholm, where top names in the world of design, fashion, art, communication and architecture were invited to talk. Amongst the international speakers were [[Ruth Ansel]], [[Barbara Kruger]], [[Janet Froelich]] and [[Cindy Gallop]].
In 2013, Hall of Femmes received the Bengt Hanser Award, presented by the Swedish Association of Communication Agencies.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.komm.se/fakta2/bengt-hanser-stipendiet|title=Komm on the Bengt Hanser Award|publisher=Komm|date=2013-05-01 |accessdate=2014-03-26}}</ref>
== List of Hall of Femmes books == * '''[[Barbara Stauffacher Solomon]]''', ''I broke all the rules.'' * '''[[Janet Froelich]]''', ''I love the hunt for the story, the thread of the narrative.'' * '''[[Lella Vignelli]]''', ''My ideas are always clear.'' * '''[[Tomoko Miho]]''', ''Good design is about finding solutions.'' * '''[[Paula Scher]]''', ''Style changes, technology changes, but people never change.'' * '''[[Lillian Bassman]]''', ''I've never not worked. I'm 93 years old and I've been working since I was 15.'' * '''[[Carin Goldberg]]''', ''Think. Look. Listen. Ask question. Have fun. Assume nothing.'' * '''[[Ruth Ansel]]''', ''Magpie aesthetic*, shameless borrower, intuitive, and deceptively simple.''
== References == {{reflist}}
== External links == * [http://halloffemmes.com/ The Official Hall of Femmes Website]
[[Category:Women in Sweden]] [[Category:Cultural organizations in Sweden]]
{{art-org-stub}} {{Sweden-stub}}

{{Use American English|date=April 2017}} {{Infobox spaceflight | name = Intelsat IV F-8 | image = | image_size = | image_caption =
| mission_type = [[Communications satellite|Communications]] | operator = [[Intelsat]] | website = | COSPAR_ID = 1974-093A | SATCAT = 07544 | mission_duration = 7 years (planned)
| spacecraft_bus = [[Spacebus|HS-312]] | spacecraft_type = | manufacturer = [[Hughes Aircraft]] | BOL_mass = {{convert|730|kg|lb}} | launch_mass = {{convert|1414|kg|lb}} | dimensions = | power =
| launch_date = {{start-date|November 21, 1974, 23:43:59|timezone=yes}} UTC<ref name="launchlog">{{cite web|url=http://planet4589.org/space/log/launchlog.txt|title=Launch Log|first=Jonathan|last=McDowell|work=Jonathan's Space Page|accessdate=April 22, 2017}}</ref> | launch_rocket = [[Atlas-Centaur|Atlas SLV-3D Centaur-D1AR]] | launch_site = [[Cape Canaveral Air Force Station|Cape Canaveral]] [[Cape Canaveral Air Force Station Space Launch Complex 36|LC-36B]] | launch_contractor =
| disposal_type = | deactivated =
| orbit_epoch = June 13, 1972<ref name="nssdc">{{cite web|url=https://nssdc.gsfc.nasa.gov/nmc/spacecraftOrbit.do?id=1974-093A|title=INTELSAT 4 F-8|first=Goddard Space Flight Center|last=NASA|work=NSSDC Master Catalog|accessdate=April 22, 2017}}</ref> | orbit_reference = [[geocentric orbit|Geocentric]]<ref name="nssdc"/> | orbit_regime = [[Geostationary orbit|Geostationary]]<ref name="nssdc"/> | orbit_periapsis = {{convert|289|km|mi|sp=us}}<ref name="nssdc"/> | orbit_apoapsis = {{convert|35,899.1|km|mi|sp=us}}<ref name="nssdc"/> | orbit_inclination = 26°<ref name="nssdc"/> | orbit_eccentricity = 0.72739<ref name="nssdc"/> | orbit_period = 639.8 minutes<ref name="nssdc"/> | orbit_longitude = | apsis = gee
| trans_band = 12 [[IEEE]] [[C band (IEEE)|C-band]] | trans_frequency = | trans_bandwidth = 40 MHz | trans_capacity = | trans_coverage = | trans_TWTA = | trans_EIRP = | trans_HPBW =
| programme = ''Intelsat IV'' | previous_mission = [[Intelsat IV F-7]] | next_mission = [[Intelsat IVA F-1]] (Intelsat IVA) }} '''Intelsat IV F-8''' was a [[geostationary]] [[communication]] [[satellite]] built by [[Hughes Aircraft Company|Hughes]], it was owned by [[Intelsat]]. The satellite was based on the [[Spacebus|HS-312]] platform and its estimated useful life was 7 years.
== History == The Intelsat IV F-8 was part of the Intelsat IV series which consisted of eight communications satellites, launched from [[Cape Canaveral]] during the early 1970s, marked the fifth generation of geostationary communications satellites developed by the [[Hughes Aircraft Company]] since 1963 with the launch of Syncom II, the world's first synchronous satellite. The [[Syncom]] II was 15 cm high and 28 inches in diameter, weighing 78 pounds in orbit. In contrast, the Intelsat IVs weighed more than [[Pound (mass)|£]] 1,300 (595 kg) into orbit and were more than 17 feet (5.31 meters) in [[diameter]]. All seven satellites exceeded their projected life expectancies and were withdrawn from active duty, the last of which, the [[Intelsat IV F-1]] was retired in October 1987.
The satellite was equipped with 12 [[C band (IEEE)|C-band]] transponders. It had 6,000 two-way [[relay]] phone calls or broadcast 12 concurrent color television programs or mixed combinations of communications traffic including data and fax.
The satellite had 12 channels of broadband communication. Each channel had a bandwidth of 40 MHz and provided about 500 communication circuits.
== Release == The satellite was successfully launched into space on November 21, 1974, at 23:43 UTC, by means of an [[Atlas-Centaur]] vehicle from the [[Cape Canaveral Air Force Station]] in [[Florida]], [[United States]]. It had a launch mass of 1,414 kg.<ref>Krebs, Gunter. [http://space.skyrocket.de/doc_sdat/intelsat-4a.htm Intelsat-4A]. ''Gunter's Space Page''. Retrieved 22 April 2017.</ref>
==See also== {{Portal|Spaceflight}} * [[1974 in spaceflight]]

The investigation was commissioned jointly by the [[United Nations]] Co-ordination Unit (UNCU) and the [[Office of the United Nations High Commissioner for Human Rights]]. The investigation concluded with a report confirming the crime of genocide to have taken place against the Isaaqs in Somalia. United Nations investigator, Chris Mburu, stated:
Based on the totality of evidence collected in Somaliland and elsewhere both during and after his mission, the consultant firmly believes that the crime of genocide was conceived, planned and perpetrated by the Somali Government against the Isaaq people of northern Somalia between 1987 and 1989.{{Cite book |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=7w8VAQAAIAAJ&q=%22Based+on+the+totality+of+evidence+collected+in+Somaliland%22&dq=%22Based+on+the+totality+of+evidence+collected+in+Somaliland%22&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwiR_vOU_b_TAhVpCMAKHUm3CiUQ6AEIJTAA |title=Past human rights abuses in Somalia: report of a preliminary study conducted for the United Nations (OHCHR/UNDP-Somalia) |last=Mburu |first=Chris |last2=Rights |first2=United Nations Office of the High Commissioner for Human |last3=Office |first3=United Nations Development Programme Somalia Country |date=2002-01-01 |publisher=s.n. |language=en}}
== Background == === Postcolonial era === The first Somali state to be granted its independence from colonial powers was [[British Somaliland|Somaliland]], a former British protectorate that gained independence on 26 June 1960. The rest of what came to be known as [[Somali Republic]] was under Italian rule under the title [[Trust Territory of Somaliland]] (also known as ''Somalia Italiana''). Shortly after [[Somaliland]] gained independence, it was to form a hasty union with its southern neighbour to create the Somali Republic. Henceforth British Somaliland was referred to as the northern (or north western) region of the Somali Republic, whilst the former Italian colonial state was referred to as the south. Within British Somaliland the Isaaq constituted the majority group within the protectorate{{Cite book |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=IfgxAQAAQBAJ&pg=PA2 |title=Consider Somaliland: State-Building with Traditional Leaders and Institutions |last=Renders |first=Marleen |date=20 January 2012 |publisher=BRILL |isbn=9789004222540 |language=en}} with [[Dir (clan)|Dir]] and Harti groups also having sizeable populations to the west and east of Isaaq respectively. The union of the two states proved problematic early on when in a referendum held on 20 June 1961 to approve the provisional constitution that would govern the two ex-colonial territories was rejected by half of the population in the [[Somaliland]] (the north-west of nascent Somali Republic), the major cities of the former British protectorate voted against the ratification of the constitution – Hargeisa (72%), Berbera (69%), Burao (66%) and Erigavo (69%) – all returned negative votes.{{Cite book |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=lEx6HIaaGfcC&pg=PA78 |title=Crisis Management and the Politics of Reconciliation in Somalia: Statements from the Uppsala Forum, 17-19 January 1994 |last=Salih |first=Mohamed Abdel Rahim Mohamed |last2=Wohlgemuth |first2=Lennart |date=1 January 1994 |publisher=Nordic Africa Institute |isbn=9789171063564 |language=en}} This was in contrast to the south (ex-Italian colony) which returned a strong support for the constitution (and four times the expected vote numbers in the south, indicating electoral fraud, an example of this is a small southern village called Wanla Weyn registered a yes vote higher than the 100,000 votes counted in all of the north),{{Cite book |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=iF8wAQAAIAAJ&q=wanla+weyn&dq=wanla+weyn&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwjKl5e9te_RAhXJAcAKHfczBX04ChDoAQgiMAI |title=Somalia calling: the crisis of statehood, and the quest for peace |last=Abraham |first=Knife |date=1 January 2002 |publisher=Ethiopian International Institute for Peace and Development |isbn=9789163119835 |language=en}} this was major signal of discontent coming from the north only a year after forming the union. Another example of the simmering discontent in the north was a coup attempt by northern officers that was thwarted in 1961.{{Cite book |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=r8rbBfTM0AgC&pg=PA303 |title=Arms for the Horn: U.S. Security Policy in Ethiopia and Somalia, 1953–1991 |last=Lefebvre |first=Jeffrey A. |date=15 January 1992 |publisher=University of Pittsburgh Pre |isbn=978-0-8229-7031-6 |language=en}} === Social, political and economic marginalisation === The northern dissatisfaction with the constitution and terms of unification was a subject that the successive civilian governments continued to ignore. The northerns, especially the majority Isaaq, believed that the unified state would be divided federally (north and south) and that they would receive a fair share of representation post unification. The south proceeded to dominate all of the important posts of the new state, this included the President, Prime Minister, Minister of Defence, Minister of Interior and Minister of Foreign Affairs posts all given to politicians hailing from the south.{{Cite book |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=ti6GDAAAQBAJ&pg=PA108 |title=The Colonial Legacy in Somalia: Rome and Mogadishu: from Colonial Administration to Operation Restore Hope |last=Tripodi |first=P. |date=2 August 1999 |publisher=Springer |isbn=978-0-333-98290-7 |language=en}} The political marginalisation that majority of northerners felt was further exacerbated by economic deprivation, the north received just under 7 percent of nationally disbursed development assistance by the late 1970s,{{Cite book |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=Sa2HDAAAQBAJ&pg=PA133&lpg=PA133&dq=&source=bl&ots=pO-vr1qvee&sig=d9iy8bTJZXguD8hXXsSjwgQA6dU&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwjf35jHq_TRAhVkF8AKHc58D-4Q6AEIGjAA#v=snippet&q=receiving%20under%207%20per%20cent%20of%20nationally%20disbursed%20development%20assistance&f=false |title=Contested States in World Politics |last=Geldenhuys |first=D. |date=22 April 2009 |publisher=Springer |isbn=978-0-230-23418-5 |language=en}} as more than 95% of all development projects and scholarships were distributed in the south. One example is cited by Hassan Megag Samater, the former director in charge of the Ministry of Education in Somaliland, he states that he had handed his post in 1966 with the northern region having "several hundred schools at all levels, from elementary schools to college. By the last year of the Barre regime, there was not a single school functioning at full strength."{{Cite book |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=lEx6HIaaGfcC&pg=PA78 |title=Crisis Management and the Politics of Reconciliation in Somalia: Statements from the Uppsala Forum, 17-19 January 1994 |last=Salih |first=Mohamed Abdel Rahim Mohamed |last2=Wohlgemuth |first2=Lennart |date=1 January 1994 |publisher=Nordic Africa Institute |isbn=9789171063564 |language=en}} === 1969 coup === In October 1969 the military seized power in a coup following the assassination of President [[Abdirashid Ali Shermarke]] and the ensuing political parliamentary debate on succession which ended in a deadlock.{{Cite book |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=Q82saX1HVQYC&pg=PA523 |title=Ethnic Groups in Conflict |last=Horowitz |first=Donald L. |date=1 January 1985 |publisher=University of California Press |isbn=978-0-520-05385-4 |language=en}} The army banned political parties, suspended the constitution and closed the National Assembly, General Siad Barre was chosen as the head of state and presided over the supreme revolutionary council.{{Cite book |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=WspaBAAAQBAJ&pg=PA31 |title=The New Pirates: Modern Global Piracy from Somalia to the South China Sea |last=Palmer |first=Andrew |date=30 July 2014 |publisher=I.B.Tauris |isbn=978-1-84885-633-2 |language=en}} The new regime outlawed political dissent and employed a heavy handed approach in managing the state. The United Nations Development Programme stated that "the 21-year regime of Siyad Barre had one of the worst human rights records in Africa."{{Cite book |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=7PLsAAAAMAAJ&q=&dq=%22regime+of+Siyad+Barre+had+one+of+the+worst+human+rights+records+in+Africa.%22&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwiZp7nWy6zYAhWKB8AKHfNRBCMQ6AEIOzAD |title=Human development report, Somalia 2001 |last=Programme |first=United Nations Development |date=2001 |publisher=United Nations Development Programme, Somalia Country Office |language=en |access-date=28 December 2017 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20171228172000/https://books.google.com/books?id=7PLsAAAAMAAJ&q=&dq=%22regime+of+Siyad+Barre+had+one+of+the+worst+human+rights+records+in+Africa.%22&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwiZp7nWy6zYAhWKB8AKHfNRBCMQ6AEIOzAD |archive-date=28 December 2017 |dead-url=no |df=}} The new regime became a client state of the Soviet Union and on the first anniversary of the coup officially adopted '[[Scientific socialism]] as its core ideology.{{Cite book |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=Ke6KnOHoo3IC&pg=PA118 |title=The Soviet Union in the Horn of Africa: The Diplomacy of Intervention and Disengagement |last=Patman |first=Robert G. |date=12 March 2009 |publisher=Cambridge University Press |isbn=978-0-521-10251-3 |language=en}} == Prelude == === Ethio-Somali War === {{Main|Ogaden War}} Successive Somali governments had continually supported the cause of [[Greater Somalia|Somali irredentism]] and the concept of 'Greater Somalia', a powerful sentiment many Somalis carried, as a core goal of the state. This particularly had strong support from the Isaaq clan who notably sent many volunteers, especially in 1976 as they joined WSLF guerrilla insurgencies and sent many volunteers a year before the war took place. Another factor behind the strong support from the Isaaq was the fact that the border that was drawn between Ethiopia and Somalia cut off important grazing grounds for Isaaq tribesmen. Barre along with the [[Supreme Revolutionary Council (Somalia)|Supreme Revolutionary Council]], to entrench their rule and in an attempt to regain the [[Somali Region]] of [[Ethiopia]], launched a war against Ethiopia in 1977, this war was referred to in Somalia as 'The War for Western Somalia'.{{Cite book |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=Vzi6CwAAQBAJ&pg=PA312 |title=The Suicidal State in Somalia: The Rise and Fall of the Siad Barre Regime, 1969–1991 |last=Ingiriis |first=Mohamed Haji |date=1 April 2016 |publisher=UPA |isbn=978-0-7618-6720-3 |language=en}} The Soviet Union, which at the time was allied to both Somalia and Ethiopia turned against Barre,{{Cite book |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=hal_DAAAQBAJ&pg=PA231 |title=Africa 2016–2017 |last=Wiafe-Amoako |first=Francis |date=28 July 2016 |publisher=Rowman & Littlefield |isbn=978-1-4758-2903-7 |language=en}} and (with their allies) provided enough support to the Ethiopian army to defeat the Somali forces and force a withdrawal from the Somali region of Ethiopia.{{Cite book |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=08OV704armMC&pg=PA1405&dq=ogaden+defeat+barre+1977&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwj_6JjknvLRAhWqCsAKHaIBByEQ6AEIJDAC#v=onepage&q=ogaden%20defeat%20barre%201977&f=false |title=Encyclopedia of the Developing World |last=Leonard |first=Thomas M. |date=1 January 2006 |publisher=Taylor & Francis |isbn=978-0-415-97664-0 |language=en}} === Displacement of Isaaq and arming of refugees === All of Somalia felt the impact of the Ogaden War defeat, however the northern region (where Isaaqs live) experienced the majority of the physical and human destruction due to its geographical proximity to the fighting.{{Cite book |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=vz6gCwAAQBAJ&pg=PA90 |title=Understanding Statebuilding: Traditional Governance and the Modern State in Somaliland |last=Richards |first=Rebecca |date=24 February 2016 |publisher=Routledge |isbn=978-1-317-00466-0 |language=en}} Somalia's defeat in the [[Ethio-Somali War]] caused an influx of Ethiopian refugees (mostly ethnic Somalis and some [[Oromo people|Oromo]]){{Cite book |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=ahHabajshuwC&pg=PA123 |title=State Collapse and Post-conflict Development in Africa: The Case of Somalia (1960–2001) |last=Mohamoud |first=Abdullah A. |date=1 January 2006 |publisher=Purdue University Press |isbn=978-1-55753-413-2 |language=en}} across the border to Somalia. By 1979, official figures reported 1.3 million refugees in Somalia, more than half of them were settled in Isaaq lands in the north.{{Cite book |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=hal_DAAAQBAJ&pg=PA231 |title=Africa 2016–2017 |last=Wiafe-Amoako |first=Francis |date=28 July 2016 |publisher=Rowman & Littlefield |isbn=978-1-4758-2903-7 |language=en}} This has caused great deal of burden on both the local Isaaqs and state apparatus, especially coming off a costly war with Ethiopia, Somali studies scholar I. M. Lewis noted that "the stark fact remained that the economy of the country simply did not possess the resources to absorb so many uprooted people."{{Cite book |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=idcVAQAAIAAJ&dq=understanding+somalia+and+somaliland:+culture,+history,+society&focus=searchwithinvolume&q=the+stark+fact+remained+that+the+economy+of+the+country+simply+ |title=Understanding Somalia and Somaliland: Culture, History, Society |last=Lewis |first=I. M. |date=1 January 2008 |publisher=Hurst |isbn=978-1-85065-898-6 |language=en}} The presence of such a large number of refugees, especially when Somalia's total population at the time was 4.1 million (UN estimates{{Cite book |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=uNxGlBCEHHMC&pg=PA164 |title=Generating Employment and Incomes in Somalia: Report of an Inter-disciplinary Employment and Project-identification Mission to Somalia Financed by the United Nations Development Programme and Executed by ILO/JASPA. |date=1 January 1989 |publisher=International Labour Organization |isbn=9789221060574 |language=en}}) meant that virtually one out of every four people in Somalia was a refugee.{{Cite book |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=DRAOAQAAMAAJ&dq=Understanding+Somalia+and+Somaliland:+Culture,+History,+Society&focus=searchwithinvolume&q=one+in+four+people |title=Understanding Somalia and Somaliland: Culture, History, Society |last=Lewis |first=I. M. |date=1 January 2008 |publisher=Hurst |isbn=978-1-85065-898-6 |language=en}} The Barre regime exploited the presence of such a large number of refugees as means of seeking foreign aid,{{Cite book |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=HT7FBQAAQBAJ&pg=PA29&lpg=PA29&dq=%22&source=bl&ots=ozHrQm_tnK&sig=ONXNGrbsS4TR-nrBBwCnfvrbMhg&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwiE_pivxPLRAhVIxxQKHeIjCssQ6AEIGjAA#v=onepage&q=%22as%20a%20justification%20for%20seeking%20foreign%20aid%22&f=false |title=The New Pirates: Modern Global Piracy from Somalia to the South China Sea |last=Palmer |first=Andrew |date=15 August 2014 |publisher=I.B.Tauris |isbn=978-0-85773-493-8 |language=en}} as well as a vehicle to displacing those deemed hostile to the state, notably the Isaaqs, [[Human Rights Watch]] noted that:
"Northerners [Isaaqs] were dismissed from and not allowed to work in government offices dealing with refugee affairs, so that they would not discover the truth about the government's policies. Instead refugees, registered with UNHCR were given jobs in the offices dealing with refugee matters."{{Cite book |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=HT7FBQAAQBAJ&pg=PA29&lpg=PA29&dq=%22government+offices+dealing+with+refugee+affairs,+so+that+%22&source=bl&ots=ozHrQm_tnK&sig=ONXNGrbsS4TR-nrBBwCnfvrbMhg&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwiE_pivxPLRAhVIxxQKHeIjCssQ6AEIGjAA#v=onepage&q=%22government%20offices%20dealing%20with%20refugee%20affairs,%20so%20that%20%22&f=false |title=The New Pirates: Modern Global Piracy from Somalia to the South China Sea |last=Palmer |first=Andrew |date=2014-08-15 |publisher=I.B.Tauris |isbn=978-0-85773-493-8 |language=en}}
As the state became increasingly reliant on international aid, aid resources allocated for the refugees caused further resentment from the local Isaaq residents, especially as they felt no effort was made on the government's part to compensate them for bearing the burden of the war.{{Cite book |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=vz6gCwAAQBAJ&pg=PA90 |title=Understanding Statebuilding: Traditional Governance and the Modern State in Somaliland |last=Richards |first=Rebecca |date=24 February 2016 |publisher=Routledge |isbn=978-1-317-00466-0 |language=en}} Furthermore, Barre heavily favoured the Ogaden refugees, who belonged to the same clan ([[Darod]]) as him. Due to these ties, the Ogaden refugees enjoyed preferential access to "social services, business licenses and even government posts."{{Cite book |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=vz6gCwAAQBAJ&pg=PA90 |title=Understanding Statebuilding: Traditional Governance and the Modern State in Somaliland |last=Richards |first=Rebecca |date=24 February 2016 |publisher=Routledge |isbn=978-1-317-00466-0 |language=en}} As expressed animosity and discontent in the north grew, Barre armed the Ogaden refugees, and in doing so created an irregular army operating inside Isaaq territories, the regime's use of armed refugees against local Isaaq populations in the north is also referenced in an Africa Watch report:
"[M]any Ogadeni refugees were recruited into the [[Western Somali Liberation Front|WSLF]]. The WSLF was ostensibly being trained to fight Ethiopia to regain the Ogaden [Western Somalia], but, in fact, terrorized the Isaak [Isaaq] civilian population living in the border region, which came to fear them more than the Ethiopian army. Killings, rape and looting became common."
Barre was essentially ensuring the loyalty of the Ogaden refugees through continued preferential treatment and protection at the expense of the local Isaaq who were not only bypassed for economic, social and political advancement but also forcefully suppressed by both the Somali Armed Forces and the Ogaden refugee militias. The settlement of Ogaden refugees in Isaaq territory, and the arming of these groups (which effectively created a foreign army in the north{{Cite book |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=DZJPm2j2iz4C&pg=PA41 |title=What are Somalia's Development Perspectives?: Science Between Resignation and Hope? : Proceedings of the 6th SSIA Congress, Berlin 6-9 December 1996 |last=Janzen |first=Jörg |last2=Vitzthum |first2=Stella von |date=1 January 2001 |publisher=Verlag Hans Schiler |isbn=978-3-86093-230-8 |language=en}}), further antagonised local Isaaq population. The armed Ogaden refugees, together with members of the Marehan and Dhulbahanta soldiers (whom were provoked and encouraged by the Barre regime) started a campaign of terror against the local Isaaqs{{Cite book |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=DZJPm2j2iz4C&pg=PA41 |title=What are Somalia's Development Perspectives?: Science Between Resignation and Hope? : Proceedings of the 6th SSIA Congress, Berlin 6-9 December 1996 |last=Janzen |first=Jörg |last2=Vitzthum |first2=Stella von |date=1 January 2001 |publisher=Verlag Hans Schiler |isbn=978-3-86093-230-8 |language=en}} as they raped women, murdered unarmed civilians, and prevented families from conducting proper burials. Barre ignored Isaaq complaints throughout the 1980s, this along with Barre's repression of criticism or discussions of the widespread atrocities in the north had the effect of turning the long-standing Isaaq disaffection into open opposition. ==== Creation of refugee Ogaden militia ==== The government started a program of creating paramilitary groups among the Ogaden refugees as well as conscripting them into the national army, it also encouraged the creation of armed militia groups among members of the Darod (the clan of Siad Barre).{{Cite book |url=http://www.sahistory.org.za/sites/default/files/file%20uploads%20/africa_watch_somalia_a_government_at_war_with_ibook4you.pdf |title=Somalia: A Government at War with Its Own People |last= |first= |publisher=Human Rights Watch |year=1990 |isbn= |location= |pages=31 |quote= |via= |access-date=16 February 2017 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170217070406/http://www.sahistory.org.za/sites/default/files/file%20uploads%20/africa_watch_somalia_a_government_at_war_with_ibook4you.pdf |archive-date=17 February 2017 |dead-url=no |df=}} The Somali Army managed the training of both groups, and costs incurred including any expenditure for their arms and equipment, radio communications and fuel came from the army's budget. One of the militias formed by the Ogaden refugees was the [[Western Somali Liberation Front|WSLF]], officially created to fight Ethiopia and "reclaim ethnic Somali territory" in Ethiopia{{Cite book |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=qrWDDAAAQBAJ&pg=PA160&lpg=PA160&dq=&source=bl&ots=aIJWzKRJIR&sig=9a6WSxjX317FmqcIl7MDND2gSNw&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwiVz4X9-JTSAhVFOhQKHUXBAVEQ6AEIGjAA#v=onepage&q=reclaim%20ethnic%20Somali%20territory&f=false |title=Globalization, Self-Determination and Violent Conflict |last=FitzGerald |first=V. |last2=Stewart |first2=F. |last3=Venugopal |first3=R. |date=5 May 2006 |publisher=Springer |isbn=978-0-230-50237-6 |language=en}} but it was used primarily against local Isaaq civilians and nomads.{{Cite book |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=qrWDDAAAQBAJ&pg=PA160&lpg=PA160&dq=&source=bl&ots=aIJWzKRJIR&sig=9a6WSxjX317FmqcIl7MDND2gSNw&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwiVz4X9-JTSAhVFOhQKHUXBAVEQ6AEIGjAA#v=onepage&q=barre%20armed%20ogadeeni%20refugees%20fight%20isaaq&f=false |title=Globalization, Self-Determination and Violent Conflict |last=FitzGerald |first=V. |last2=Stewart |first2=F. |last3=Venugopal |first3=R. |date=5 May 2006 |publisher=Springer |isbn=978-0-230-50237-6 |language=en}} A [[Human Rights Watch]]'s Africa Watch report states "The WSLF was ostensibly being trained to fight Ethiopia to regain the Ogaden, but, in fact, terrorized the Isaak civilian population living in the border region, which came to fear them more than the Ethiopian army. Killing, rape and looting became common." As the WSLF, supported by the Barre regime, continued to attack and commit atrocities against the Isaaq, a delegation was sent to meet President Barre in 1979 to request making a stop to WSLF abuses. In spite of promises made to the Isaaq elders the violence against civilians and nomads by WSLF continued. The continued abuse of WSLF and the government's indifference to the suffering of Isaaq civilians and nomads prompted many Isaaq army officers to desert the army with a view to creating their own armed movement to fight Ethiopia, one that would also intimidate the WSLF and discourage further violence against Isaaq civilians. Their new movement, supported and financed by Isaaqs, was named ''Afraad'' (the fourth unit) and became operational in 1979.{{Cite book |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=RcVFXUwraxsC&pg=PA95 |title=Evil Days: Thirty Years of War and Famine in Ethiopia |last=Waal |first=Alexander De |last2=(Organization) |first2=Human Rights Watch |date=1 January 1991 |publisher=Human Rights Watch |isbn=978-1-56432-038-4 |language=en}}{{Cite book |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=Z9x3HB7M5LgC&pg=PA123 |title=Land ohne Staat: Wirtschaft und Gesellschaft im Krieg am Beispiel Somalias |last=Bakonyi |first=Jutta |date=16 February 2017 |publisher=Campus Verlag |isbn=978-3-593-39528-9 |language=de}} The Isaaq movement of Afraad immediately came into conflict with the Ogaden clan's faction of WSLF in the form of a number of bloody encounters between the two groups. Afraad's objective was to push the WSLF out of their strongholds (Isaaq territory) whereas the WSLF responded by retaliating further against Isaaq civilians living in the border region. The situation was further exacerbated by the appointment of Mohamed Hashi Gani, a cousin of President Siad Barre and fellow [[Marehan]] [[Darod]], as the military commander of the northern regions with headquarters in Hargeisa in 1980.{{Cite book |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=DPwOsOcNy5YC&pg=PA99 |title=Historical Dictionary of Somalia |last=Mukhtar |first=Mohamed Haji |date=25 February 2003 |publisher=Scarecrow Press |isbn=978-0-8108-6604-1 |language=en}} Gani's rule was especially harsh against Isaaq, he removed them from all key economic positions, seized their properties and placed the northern regions under emergency laws. He also ordered the transfer of Afraad away from the border region, giving the WSLF complete control of the border region, thus leaving Isaaq nomads in the area without any protection against WSLF violence. A [[United Nations]] inspection team that visited the area in 1988 reported that the Ethiopian refugees (Ogaden) were carrying weapons supplied by the Somali Army. The UN team reported that, with the Somali Army's encouragement, the Ogadeni refugees carried out extensive looting in several northern towns. === Isaaq uprising === By early 1978 the Barre regime had full control of the Somali state's economic apparatus, including large amounts of foreign aid which were deployed "using selective redistribution to ensure loyalty to the regime."{{Cite book |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=vz6gCwAAQBAJ&pg=PA90 |title=Understanding Statebuilding: Traditional Governance and the Modern State in Somaliland |last=Richards |first=Rebecca |date=24 February 2016 |publisher=Routledge |isbn=978-1-317-00466-0 |language=en}} The Barre regime's oppressive policies against the Isaaq continued when in 1981, the Barre regime declared economic warfare on Somalis from the northwest and specifically the Isaaq.{{Cite book |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=PBvfTmzsZ-0C&pg=PA84&lpg=PA84&dq=declared+economic+warfare+on+somalis+from+the+northwestern&source=bl&ots=gnZjvBN3U7&sig=fpCzxequi-kh0_j9lEMlEkQ_ER8&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwje28T_k_7RAhXmBsAKHRN2CVkQ6AEIGjAA#v=onepage&q=declared%20economic%20warfare%20on%20somalis%20from%20the%20northwestern&f=false |title=Clan Cleansing in Somalia: The Ruinous Legacy of 1991 |last=Kapteijns |first=Lidwien |date=18 December 2012 |publisher=University of Pennsylvania Press |isbn=0-8122-0758-0 |language=en}} This was a major cause of the eventual fall of the Barre regime in 1991. It led a group of Isaaq businesspeople, students, former civil servants and former politicians who lived in the United Kingdom{{Cite book |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=nrN077AEgzMC&pg=PA679 |title=Civil Wars of the World: Major Conflicts Since World War II |last=Jr |first=Karl DeRouen |last2=Heo |first2=Uk |date=28 March 2007 |publisher=ABC-CLIO |isbn=978-1-85109-919-1 |language=en}}{{Cite book |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=vz6gCwAAQBAJ&pg=PA90 |title=Understanding Statebuilding: Traditional Governance and the Modern State in Somaliland |last=Richards |first=Rebecca |date=24 February 2016 |publisher=Routledge |isbn=978-1-317-00466-0 |language=en}} to found the [[Somali National Movement]] in London in April 1981. Initially, the aim of the various groups that merged to create the SNM was not to create an armed liberation front, but rather these groups formed as a direct response to the harsh policies enacted by the Barre regime against the Isaaqs. However, the official position changed following the meeting of the newly formed SNM Congress in October 1981 to one of liberation 'with the expressed aim of ridding Somalia of Barre and instituting a democratic government in Somalia that would be inclusive of and based on the clan system." Ideologically, the SNM was a Western-leaning movement and was described as "one of the most democratic movements in the Horn of Africa."{{Cite book |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=26QaAQAAMAAJ&q=&dq=%22one+of+the+most+democratic+movements+in+the+Horn+of+Africa%22&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwjU4-3u1YDSAhULIsAKHTTAALYQ6AEIHjAB |title=Somalia: the case for action : hearing before the Select Committee on Hunger, House of Representatives, One Hundred Second Congress, second session, hearing held in Washington, DC, July 22, 1992 |last=Hunger |first=United States Congress House Select Committee on |date=1 January 1992 |publisher=U.S. G.P.O. |isbn=978-0-16-039742-4 |language=en}} A [[Human Rights Watch]] testimony before the [[United States Congress]]' Africa Subcommittee on 14 July 1988 stated that the actions of the Barre government have "created a level of violence unprecedented in scope and duration in Somalia". The testimony of [[Aryeh Neier]] (co-founder of [[Human Rights Watch|HRW]]) explains the context in which the SNM was formed:
Since 1981, with the formation of the SNM, northern Somalia has seen the worst atrocities. Serious human right violations, including extra-judicial executions of unarmed civilians, detentions without trial, unfair trials, torture, rape, looting and extortion, have been a prominent feature of life in the towns and countryside in the northern region since 1981. In order to deprive the SNM of a civilian base of support in their area of operation, those living in rural areas between Hargeisa and the Ethiopian border have suffered particularly brutal treatment. A scorched earth policy that involved the burning of farms, the killing of livestock, the destruction of water-storage tanks and the deliberate poisoning of wells, has been pursued actively by the military. The principal towns have been subjected to a curfew for several years; arbitrary restrictions on the extension of the curfew have facilitated extortion by soldiers and curfew patrols. Internal travel is controlled through military checkpoints .... The existence of the SNM has provided a pretext for President Barre and his military deputies in the north to wage a war against peaceful citizens and to enable them to consolidate their control of the country by terrorizing anyone who is suspected of not being wholeheartedly pro-government. Years of sustained state violence have created a serious level of political unrest in the region.
The atmosphere of lawlessness has enabled soldiers to harass civilians for the purposes of extortion. Many Somalis have reported that military and security officers only respond to inquiries by detainees' relatives with promises to secure their release in exchange for cash payments. Civilians living in [[Burao|Buroa]] and [[Hargeisa]] have frequently been forbidden to hold funerals for relatives shot dead by the military and curfew patrols until they have paid a ransom. Rape, of young and older women, is routine. They will only be released from detention centers, even after being raped, if the family pays a ransom. No soldier or member of the security forces has ever been disciplined or prosecuted for abuses, which highlights the general lack of accountability.{{Cite book |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=uJZWboQa6B0C&q=%22Since+1981,+with+the+formation+of+the+SNM,+northern+Somalia%22&dq=%22Since+1981,+with+the+formation+of+the+SNM,+northern+Somalia%22&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwjR1ZDC-J7TAhWIDsAKHbJyANwQ6AEIIzAA |title=Reported Massacres and Indiscriminate Killings in Somalia: Hearing Before the Subcommittee on Africa of the Committee on Foreign Affairs, House of Representatives, One Hundredth Congress, Second Session, July 14, 1988 |last=Africa |first=United States Congress House Committee on Foreign Affairs Subcommittee on |date=1989-01-01 |publisher=U.S. Government Printing Office |language=en}}
By 1982 the SNM transferred their headquarters to [[Dire Dawa]] in Ethiopia,{{Cite book |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=IXdqkSH4S7EC&pg=PA25 |title=Somalia: Issues, History, and Bibliography |last=Fitzgerald |first=Nina J. |date=1 January 2002 |publisher=Nova Publishers |isbn=978-1-59033-265-8 |language=en}} as both Somalia and Ethiopia at the time offered safe havens of operation for resistance groups against each other. From there the SNM successfully launched a guerrilla war against the Barre regime through incursions and [[Hit and run (military)|hit and run]] operations on army positions within Isaaq territories before returning to Ethiopia.{{Cite book |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=vz6gCwAAQBAJ&pg=PA90 |title=Understanding Statebuilding: Traditional Governance and the Modern State in Somaliland |last=Richards |first=Rebecca |date=24 February 2016 |publisher=Routledge |isbn=978-1-317-00466-0 |language=en}} The SNM continued this pattern of attacks from 1982 and throughout the 1980s, at a time the Ogaden Somalis (some of whom were recruited refugees) made up the bulk of Barre's armed forces accused of committing acts of genocide against the Isaaq people of the north.{{Cite book |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=ul7vAAAAMAAJ&q=major+uprising+against+Barre+and+kept+up&dq=major+uprising+against+Barre+and+kept+up&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwjk7end9PvRAhWFipAKHVAsBV0Q6AEIHDAA |title=The Weekly Review |date=1 January 1991 |publisher=Stellascope Limited |language=en}} It was clear then that the Barre regime had labelled the entire Isaaq population as enemy of the state.{{Cite book |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=mKWiBwAAQBAJ&pg=PT149&dq=The+Isaak+population+was+labeled+as+the+enemy&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwiptMSP0oDSAhVFAcAKHeHtCIEQ6AEIHDAA#v=onepage&q=The%20Isaak%20population%20was%20labeled%20as%20the%20enemy&f=false |title=Making and Unmaking Nations: The Origins and Dynamics of Genocide in Contemporary Africa |last=Straus |first=Scott |date=24 March 2015 |publisher=Cornell University Press |isbn=978-0-8014-5567-4 |language=en}} In order to weaken support for the SNM within the Isaaqs, the government enacted a policy of systematic use of large-scale violence against the local Isaaq population. A report by Africa Watch stated that the policy was "the outcome of a specific conception of how the war against the insurgents should be fought," with the logic being to "punish civilians for their presumed support for the SNM attacks and to discourage them from further assistance."{{Cite book |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=mKWiBwAAQBAJ&pg=PT149&lpg=PT149&dq=&source=bl&ots=mLvJdMXRkn&sig=GlK10uEGjIoIOX-F5dDbqv9M2E0&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwjXkd_904DSAhUI0GMKHUjVDQ8Q6AEIGjAA#v=onepage&q=punish%20civilians%20for%20their%20presumed%20support%20for%20the%20SNM&f=false |title=Making and Unmaking Nations: The Origins and Dynamics of Genocide in Contemporary Africa |last=Straus |first=Scott |date=24 March 2015 |publisher=Cornell University Press |isbn=978-0-8014-5567-4 |language=en}} In addition to state-sponsored violence, other means of crushing the Isaaq uprising included the government's continuation of its policy of political repression and harsh economic measures, this included withholding international food aid donations to the Isaaq.{{Cite book |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=BpGXBwAAQBAJ&pg=PA277 |title=Encyclopedia of Conflicts Since World War II |last=Ciment |first=James |date=20 March 2015 |publisher=Routledge |isbn=978-1-317-47186-8 |language=en}} This was especially harsh as food aid accounted for nearly half of all food consumption in Somalia in the 1980s.{{Cite book |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=nB51_Jfd1QgC&pg=PA50 |title=People and the Earth: Basic Issues in the Sustainability of Resources and Environment |last=Rogers |first=John James William |last2=Feiss |first2=P. Geoffrey |date=13 March 1998 |publisher=Cambridge University Press |isbn=978-0-521-56872-2 |language=en}} === Planning and preparation === ==== Letter of Death ==== [[File:Letter-of-Death-1.jpg|thumb|Letter of Death (1/2) by General Mohammed Said Hersi Morgan, the son-in-law of dictator Siad Barre, a policy letter with the proposed "final solution" to Somalia's "Isaaq problem"]] [[File:Letter-of-Death-2.jpg|thumb|Letter of Death (2/2) by General Mohammed Said Hersi Morgan, the son-in-law of dictator Siad Barre, a policy letter with the proposed "final solution" to Somalia's "Isaaq problem"]] In January 1986, Barre's son-in-law and viceroy in the north General [[Mohammed Said Hersi Morgan]], who was Barre's bodyguard before he married his daughter{{Cite book |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=DPwOsOcNy5YC&pg=PA158 |title=Historical Dictionary of Somalia |last=Mukhtar |first=Mohamed Haji |date=25 February 2003 |publisher=Scarecrow Press |isbn=978-0-8108-6604-1 |language=en}} reportedly told Isaaq nomads at a waterhole "if you Isaaqs resist, we will destroy your towns, and you will inherit only ashes".{{Cite book |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=2Nu918tYMB8C&pg=PA37 |title=Culture and Customs of Somalia |last=Abdullahi |first=Mohamed Diriye |date=1 January 2001 |publisher=Greenwood Publishing Group |isbn=978-0-313-31333-2 |language=en}} General Morgan (later to be known as the Butcher of Hargeisa){{Cite web |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/world/africa/1747697.stm#mshm |title=BBC NEWS {{!}} Africa {{!}} Analysis: Somalia's powerbrokers|publisher=BBC|access-date=10 February 2017|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090414214002/http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/world/africa/1747697.stm#mshm|archive-date=14 April 2009|dead-url=no|df=}} was also responsible for the policy letter written to his father-in-law during his time as the military governor of the north,{{Cite book |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=9fAjtruUXjEC&pg=PA214 |title=Blood and Bone: The Call of Kinship in Somali Society |last=Lewis |first=I. M. |date=1 January 1994 |publisher=The Red Sea Press |isbn=978-0-932415-93-6 |language=en}} this letter came to be known as 'The Letter of Death',{{Cite book |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=ZybbAAAAMAAJ&q=%22had+written+a+letter+to+his+father-in-law,+which+subsequently+become+known+as%22&dq=%22had+written+a+letter+to+his+father-in-law,+which+subsequently+become+known+as%22&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwiZy6ba3YXSAhUJKsAKHVmuAXcQ6AEIHDAA |title=Genocide, war crimes and the West: history and complicity |last=Jones |first=Adam |date=10 February 2017 |publisher=Zed Books |isbn=978-1-84277-191-4 |language=en}}{{Cite book |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=mgAEAQAAIAAJ&q=%22In+a+now+infamous+letter+(see+AE+August,+1987)+he+had+addressed%22&dq=%22In+a+now+infamous+letter+(see+AE+August,+1987)+he+had+addressed%22&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwjKxP2j34XSAhXqCcAKHa9vCiYQ6AEIGjAA |title=Africa Events |date=1 January 1989 |publisher=Dar es Salaam Limited |language=en}} in which he "proposed the foundations for a scorched-earth policy to get rid of 'anti-Somali germs'".{{Cite book |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=2Nu918tYMB8C&pg=PA37 |title=Culture and Customs of Somalia |last=Abdullahi |first=Mohamed Diriye |date=1 January 2001 |publisher=Greenwood Publishing Group |isbn=978-0-313-31333-2 |language=en}} The policy letter (also known as the Morgan Report){{Cite book |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=vz6gCwAAQBAJ&pg=PA202 |title=Understanding Statebuilding: Traditional Governance and the Modern State in Somaliland |last=Richards |first=Rebecca |date=24 February 2016 |publisher=Routledge |isbn=978-1-317-00466-0 |language=en}} was officially a top secret report to the president on "implemented and recommended measures" for a "final solution" to Somalia's "Isaaq problem".{{Cite book |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=AX3UCk_PdEwC&pg=PA149 |title=Genocides by the Oppressed: Subaltern Genocide in Theory and Practice |last=Robins |first=Nicholas A. |last2=Jones |first2=Adam |date=1 January 2009 |publisher=Indiana University Press |isbn=0-253-22077-7 |language=en}} Morgan writes that the Isaaq people must be "subjected to a campaign of obliteration" in order to prevent the Isaaq from "rais[ing] their heads again". He continued: "Today, we possess the right remedy for the virus in the [body of the] Somali State." Some of the "remedies" he discussed included: "Balancing the well-to-do to eliminate the concentration of wealth [in the hands of Isaaq]."{{Cite book |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=7w8VAQAAIAAJ&q=%22Balancing+the+well-to-do+to+eliminate+the+concentration+of+wealth%22&dq=%22Balancing+the+well-to-do+to+eliminate+the+concentration+of+wealth%22&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwiSp8Hd6IXSAhWhAcAKHaNeD1MQ6AEIJjAD |title=Past human rights abuses in Somalia: report of a preliminary study conducted for the United Nations (OHCHR/UNDP-Somalia) |last=Mburu |first=Chris |last2=Rights |first2=United Nations Office of the High Commissioner for Human |last3=Office |first3=United Nations Development Programme Somalia Country |date=1 January 2002 |publisher=s.n. |language=en}} In addition, he called for "the reconstruction of the Local Council [in Isaaq settlements] in such a way as to balance its present membership which is exclusively from a particular people [the Isaaq]; as well as the dilution of the school population with an infusion of [Ogaden] children from the Refugee Camps in the vicinity of Hargeisa".{{Cite book |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=7w8VAQAAIAAJ&q=%22dilution+of+the+school+population+with+an+infusion+of+children%22&dq=%22dilution+of+the+school+population+with+an+infusion+of+children%22&hl=en&sa=X&redir_esc=y |title=Past human rights abuses in Somalia: report of a preliminary study conducted for the United Nations (OHCHR/UNDP-Somalia) |last=Mburu |first=Chris |last2=Rights |first2=United Nations Office of the High Commissioner for Human |last3=Office |first3=United Nations Development Programme Somalia Country |date=1 January 2002 |publisher=s.n. |language=en}} More extreme recommendations included: "Rendering uninhabitable the territory between the army and the enemy, which can be done by destroying the water tanks and the villages lying across the territory used by them for infiltration"; and "removing from the membership of the armed forces and civil service all those who are open to suspicion of aiding the enemy – especially those holding sensitive posts". In discussing the unusually frank tone of the report, Hassan Abdi Madar states:
"The report is addressed to the President of the SDR, the Minister of Defence, and Minister of Interior. The latter, Major-General Ahmed Suleiman Abdalla is also a son-in-law of the President, and Third Deputy Prime Minister. Since President Barre is also the Minister of Defence -- the previous holder of that portfolio, General [[Mohammad Ali Samatar]], having been promoted Prime Minister on January 30, 1987 -- the report is seemingly confined to family members. This would explain its extreme frankness in specifying certain clans as targets for implemented and recommended punitive action."{{Cite book |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=TXiYCgAAQBAJ&pg=PA49 |title=WARQADDII GEERIDA (Dad-qalkii Hargeysa) |last=Madar |first=Hassan Abdi |publisher=Lulu.com |isbn=978-1-329-54033-0 |language=en}}{{Self-published inline|certain=yes|date=December 2017}}
Other aims of the policy included arming other clans in the region{{Cite book |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=WspaBAAAQBAJ&pg=PA30 |title=The New Pirates: Modern Global Piracy from Somalia to the South China Sea |last=Palmer |first=Andrew |date=30 July 2014 |publisher=I.B.Tauris |isbn=978-1-84885-633-2 |language=en}} and encouraging them to fight the dominant Isaaq:
"Since it has become evident that the Isaaq were, by act and intent, with the SNM; and since we could not see them giving up the line they have pursued so deceptively for some time; and in order to forestall them; we arranged for the other inhabitants of the North continuous meetings and a mobilization campaign designed to rouse them to action and to raise their level of awareness. This was intended to strengthen their unity and to surround Somali unity with a defensive wall. Among those inhabitants are: the Awdal people, the various sections of Western Somalis [including Ogaden refugees], the Las Qorey people, and the Daami people, etc. There is no doubt that the unity of these people will restore the balance of the scales which are now tipped in favour of the Isaaq. If they attack their tasks energetically, their unity will also undoubtedly humble those who arrogantly maintain that they own the North when the reality is otherwise."{{Cite web |url=http://finalsolutiontoisaqproblem.blogspot.co.uk/2008/02/morgans-death-letter-last-solution-to.html |title=Morgan's Death Letter-The Final Solution to Somalia's Isaq Problem |website=finalsolutiontoisaqproblem.blogspot.co.uk |access-date=2017-02-10 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20171228232116/http://finalsolutiontoisaqproblem.blogspot.co.uk/2008/02/morgans-death-letter-last-solution-to.html |archive-date=2017-12-28 |dead-url=no |df=}}
=== Extrajudicial executions === [[File:Dead bodies of Hargeisa victims, June 1988.jpg|thumb|Victims of extrajudicial execution by government soldiers left in a [[Hargeisa]] street, June 1988, Amnesty International]] The system of indiscriminate killings employed by the government following SNM offensives had a galvanising effect on opposition to the government among both Isaaq nomads and city-dwellers.{{Cite book |title=Somalia: A Government at War With Its Own People |last= |first= |publisher=Human Rights Watch's Africa Watch |year=1990 |isbn= |location=https://www.hrw.org/sites/default/files/reports/somalia_1990.pdf |pages=63}} The military was operating under the assumption that if the SNM was active in a particular area, local residents must be supporters of the rebels. According to [[Human Rights Watch]]'s Africa Watch, hundreds of Isaaqs have been executed and subjected to other reprisals on the basis of such suspicions. These killing started after the SNM escalated its incursions into the Isaaq majority cities in the north. On every encounter between the SNM and government forces, "the army would conduct a sweep of the area where the incident occurred. Massacres followed, as did the killing of livestock, the use of landmines to blow up reservoirs, the burning of huts, arrests and detentions. The entire population in the area was regarded as 'the enemy'."
